title: Under-fire Arsene Wenger starts making the changes Arsenal board want to see as chairman gives rare statement
text:
Inside the 'Wenger Out' protest Share this video Watch Next 
There is a two-year contract on the table for him, but the Arsenal ­hierarchy are adamant they will see how the season plays out before ­making a decision. Wenger is sensitive to ­supporters’ ­frustration and if the run-in goes badly he will leave. 
Keswick said: “We’re fully aware of the attention ­currently focused on the club and understand the debate. 
“We respect that fans are entitled to their different ­individual opinions but we will always run this great ­football club with its best long-term ­interests at heart. Arsenal's dismal latest failure to reach the last eight of the Champions League... (Photo: AMA/Getty) ...comes as fans fear this will be the season they finally miss out on a top-four finish (Photo: PA) Read More Wenger to help pick Arsenal's new Academy boss despite speculation over own future 
“Arsene has a ­contract until the end of the season. Any decisions will be made by us mutually and communicated at the right time in the right way.” 
It is understood Thursday's ­statement was designed to take the heat off Wenger ahead of the business end of the season, which starts with Saturday's home FA Cup quarter-final against non-League giant-killers Lincoln. 
Another upset there against the Imps, who have already taken four league scalps in their run to the last eight, including away to Premier League Burnley, would really raise the pressure. But it seems increasingly likely Wenger will sign a new deal. Lincoln have beaten league sides Burnley, Brighton, Ipswich and Oldham on their Cup run (Photo: Getty) Read More ANDY DUNN: This one decision tells you Wenger's lost his grip on modern footballing reality 
If the 67-year-old does sign a new deal, it would mean a major ­rebuilding job —especially as MirrorSport understands there is an increasing chance star duo Mesut Ozil and Alexis Sanchez will both leave in the summer. 
The pair have been offered huge deals – midfielder Ozil’s proposal has a value of about £280,000-a-week – but have not committed ­themselves, which may mean Arsenal sell. French champions Paris Saint-­Germain are in pole-position to sign forward Sanchez. 
The Gunners' top brass want to believe Wenger can reinvent himself and build a new squad to bring back success. It could be a VERY different Arsenal season next season if these two both go (Photo: Arsenal FC via Getty) Read More Arsenal fans convinced club statement means writing is on the wall for Wenger 
He is showing a mood for change by tailoring training programmes for the run-in — a subtle but significant switch from the past. 
On Thursday, he made it clear he still has an appetite for the job and was not worried about his reputation being tarnished by staying too long. 
He added: “I feel very strong, very motivated, ready to give my best. What keeps me going is the love for the game, the passion for football, the ­passion for the club, the love of the uncertainly. Wenger won three league titles in his first eight seasons but has none in the last 13 (Photo: Getty) Read More JOHN CROSS: Club statement leans towards Wenger staying - but I think it would be a mistake 
“I don’t work for my image, I work for this club with full commitment. After, how will I be judged? It’s not too much my problem. 
“I think I’ve shown first of all I love this club, I’m loyal to this club and I make the right decisions for this club. I’ll ­continue to do that, while ­respecting the values I think are vital for me. If I can’t do that, I will not be here.” 
Of fans’ opinion influencing his decision, he added: “It won’t be the most important factor but of course, you ­consider it.” poll loading Should Arsene Wenger go at the end of the season? 1000+ VOTES SO FAR
